items.title: ‚ÄúThis experience of feeling unsafe in your community due to...
items.content_html:
Colorado Attorneys Against Police Violence

‚ÄúThis experience of feeling unsafe in your community due to the mere presence of police officers is an abhorrent truth for Black communities everywhere. But nothing will ever change unless there are consequences for officer actions. Treating Elijah‚Äôs case as a tragic incident and not as a symptom of tolerated and protected behavior by law enforcement as a whole, is willful and wanton negligence.

The police must be held to an unimpeachable standard. They must earn the power th...ey hold. They must honor their position of trust. And if they fail to meet that standard, they must be brought to account.

But individual reform is not good enough; we need sweeping, departmental changes ‚Äì uprooting the corrupt norms of entrenched deception and shielded abusers.

In order to do this, we must fundamentally change the way we police in this state, beginning with a top-to-bottom assessment into the policies, practices, training and mandated discipline of officers.‚Äù

https://www.denverpost.com/‚Ä¶/elijah-mcclain-death-more-cau‚Ä¶/

items.title: If DAs don‚Äôt cover up police misconduct, why is there a need...
items.content_html:
Colorado Attorneys Against Police Violence

If DAs don‚Äôt cover up police misconduct, why is there a need for independent investigations? If DAs offices are truly separate from police departments, shouldn‚Äôt their investigations be independent? To answer these questions, compare the conclusions of the independent investigation into the murder of #ElijahMcClain to elected Adams County DA Dave Young‚Äôs (now a DA in El Paso County) conclusions regarding whether APD officers had a right to contact Elijah.

The answer is simple: #DAsAreCopsToo and we must hold them accountable. Help #CAAPV in its work for DA accountability by telling us your stories of prosecutorial misconduct and discovery violations. Links in the comments. üëá

items.title: ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs already hard for family members to be in contact with...
items.content_html:
Colorado Attorneys Against Police Violence

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs already hard for family members to be in contact with their loved ones who are incarcerated in general,‚Äù said Apryl Alexander, a clinical and forensic psychologist and trauma researcher at the University of Denver. ‚ÄúNow that you add these COVID-19 precautions that limit visitation, it also limits community programs from going inside and offering services like they normally do. We‚Äôre seeing a lot more isolation and we know that it is wearing on everyone‚Äôs mental health.‚Äù...

Alexander coauthored a paper in June in the Journal of Humanistic Psychology, titled, ‚ÄúSick and Shut In: Incarceration During a Public Health Crisis.‚Äù

‚ÄúThere‚Äôs a lot of literature discussing the physical and mental health consequences of solitary confinement,‚Äù Alexander said. ‚ÄúIsolation can lead to depression, anxiety, and can cause some cognitive difficulties which intertwine with the physical constraints. Most suicides that happen in correctional settings happen when a person is in solitary confinement.‚Äù

https://coloradonewsline.com/‚Ä¶/mental-health-crisis-feare‚Ä¶/‚Ä¶

See MoreCriminal justice advocates worry prison lockdowns during the pandemic are fueling an already existing mental health crisis.

items.title: ‚ÄºÔ∏è BIG NEWS FROM #CAAPV ‚ÄºÔ∏è #CAAPV is working with Sen....
items.content_html:
Colorado Attorneys Against Police Violence

‚ÄºÔ∏è BIG NEWS FROM #CAAPV ‚ÄºÔ∏è

#CAAPV is working with Sen. Gonzales, Rep. Tipper, and Rep. Kennedy to pass a law that recognizes the immense, unchecked power of prosecutors. The bill addresses:

‚ùå Meaningful Sanctions for Discovery Violations ...
‚ùå Removal of Absolute Prosecutorial Immunity
‚ùå Increased Transparency and Mandated Reporting of Found Discovery Violations

‚ÄºÔ∏è WE NEED YOUR HELP ‚ÄºÔ∏è

DAs are saying that discovery violations simply do not happen. We know that reality is far different, and we need data to support that. At the link below, submit information on instances where a court has found a discovery violation. Gathering statewide data to show the epidemic of discovery violations is integral to passing this bill. Fill out as many as you can, and share with your friends and networks!!

https://www.caapv.org/discovery-violations

See MoreDiscovery violations happen all the time. Help CAAPV expose the very real need for DA Accountability Legislation #DAAB.

caapv.org

Discovery Violations Happen. | CAAPV

Discovery violations happen all the time. Help CAAPV expose the very real need for DA Accountability Legislation #DAAB.Discovery violations happen all the time. Help CAAPV expose the very real need for DA Accountability Legislation #DAAB.

items.title: ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a very stigmatized population, and there are people...
items.content_html:
Colorado Attorneys Against Police Violence

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a very stigmatized population, and there are people who say, ‚ÄòThey‚Äôre in prison, they must have done something terrible, and they don‚Äôt deserve a place in line,‚Äô ‚Äù said Matthew Wynia, director of the Center for Bioethics and Humanities at the University of Colorado and a member of the state‚Äôs medical advisory group. But viewing the priorities in terms of who deserves to be inoculated, he said, ‚Äúmight end up prolonging the pandemic and killing more people.‚Äù

Anyone making... a ‚Äúmoralistic argument,‚Äù Wynia said, should focus more on the math ‚Äî 14 of Colorado‚Äôs 15 largest outbreaks have occurred in prisons, jails or college dorms. Nationally, more than 40 of the 50 largest clustered outbreaks have occurred in jails and prisons, according to a ‚Äúcall for urgent action‚Äù published in the Lancet medical journal in October. Inmates live in crowded conditions and have high rates of hypertension, heart disease and other conditions linked to serious risk from covid-19, the illness caused by the coronavirus. They are disproportionately Black and Hispanic, part of communities stricken by the pandemic.

More than 7,000 people in the care of the Colorado Department of Corrections have tested positive for the virus, and the state says 24 have died. Anuj Mehta, a Denver pulmonologist who chaired the advisory group addressing vaccine prioritization, said he thought Polis was operating on a principle of ‚Äútrying to save the most lives,‚Äù though he disagrees with the governor‚Äôs approach. Viral spread hardly stays within prison walls, he noted, mainly because corrections officers return to their families, often in minority and low-income communities.‚Äù

https://www.washingtonpost.com/‚Ä¶/01/02/covid-vaccine-pris‚Ä¶/‚Ä¶

See MoreA shift in Colorado offers an early sign that prisons and jails, which disproportionately hold people of color and have reported some of the most virulent coronavirus outbreaks, are creating daunting dilemmas for state leaders apportioning finite shares of the vaccine.

washingtonpost.com

Early vaccination in prisons, a public health priority, proves politically charged

A shift in Colorado offers an early sign that prisons and jails, which disproportionately hold people of color and have reported some of the most virulent coronavirus outbreaks, are creating daunting dilemmas for state leaders apportioning finite shares of the vaccine.A shift in Colorado offers an early sign that prisons and jails, which disproportionately hold people of color and have reported some of the most virulent coronavirus outbreaks, are creating daunting dilemmas for state leaders apportioning finite shares of the vaccine.
